reviewText:
Passing Pineview Forest is a weird title, while I don't find it to be the worst game ever, I don't really think it's that good as well.

Passing Pineview Forest is a prequel title to Pineview Drive. The main goal is to walk through the woods until you reach the pineview manor, but be careful to not make much noise, cause there is a spirit in the woods and it wants to kill you.

The games main focus is audio. The audio gives you notes when playing, like when to stop and when to start moving again. The audio design is amazing and definitely the best aspect of the game.

The gameplay itself is rather tedious to say the least. The entire time I felt frustrated when I got killed when I swear that I didn't make any noise.

But the game itself is quite nerve racking at moments. Some of the sounds really creep you out and they do wonders when creating atmosphere.

The graphics are nothing too special, you will want to use as less of your flashlight as possible, so you won't really see the environments.

The game lasted me 30 minutes and apart from the one playthrough there is no replay value.

Overall Passing Pineview Forest is a really fun horror title, even though it has very tedious gameplay it's still worth to play just to get a good dose of horror, not to mention it's free.

Final Rating:
7/10 - Alright

reviewText:
Right. So, as has been mentioned before, this is less of a game and more of a proof of concept. It's cool that the developers put it out there for everrybody to try out for free. I think it took me something like 10 minutes to run through (literally, lol). It has the appearance of a game using the Unity engine as so many other games.

The actual controls are simply walk and run.

You basically start out in a dark forest, follow a path that leads you to a pair of seemingly abandoned homes that you can look around. The path then leads you to a church that you cant enter, past a cool looking statue and a creepy scarecrow, and finally to your doom courtesy of a pair of spectral hands (presented as a jump scare). Normally I would tag this with spoilers, but really, there isnt enough gameplay to warrant it.

The sound for the game is marginally ominous, and some of the ambient sounds are kind of cool. You can tell when you are close to death as the sounds shift a bit and you can hear something rustling in the forest around you.

That's pretty much all there was to this. I didnt experience the lagginess mentioned in other reviews and I also played it with maxed out settings (such as they are).

I dont know that this will really do anything to whet your appetite for the full game that is currently available on Steam, but it was interesting enough for what it was. One cause for concern however was the 2+ gig file size. I'm not sure why this wasnt compressed or what have you. Seems like it should have been more like 100mb based on the content....maybe a little more if you factor in the sounds, but defintely wasnt 2 gigs worth of content.

I'm not going to rate this as it really isnt a game as much as a proof of concept, but I'd recommend checking it out. Isnt much of a time investment and it is also free.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I have played a LOT of horror games, and I thought I was pretty much immune to being scared by now... but this game terrifies me! Something about being alone in a forest at night with only a flashlight... the sounds are really what does it. As I walk or run along the path, there are constant sounds around me, mostly rustling bushes that make me shine the flashlight in that direction and make sure nothing is sneaking up on me! The music is also unnerving, sometimes building up unexpectantly and making me jump. While playing, I find myself in a constant state of fear, walking and running along and constantly shining the flashlight around, afraid of being caught unawares.

What don't I like? The movement is incredibly slow. On the one hand, it makes you feel more vulnerable. On the other hand, it takes too long to traverse the environment, and seems like a bit of a cheap way to prolong the experience. Also, the character holds the flashlight at a weird angle. Almost like if you held it loosely in your hand with your arm at your side, so the light points more at the ground than the space in front of you. I'd much prefer a flashlight centered on the screen, it would be way more useful.

If you like first person atmospheric horror games, definitely give this a go! It's free, after all.

reviewText:
I followed the dancing shadows of the forest canopy through which a brilliant blue moon hung in the night. Watching me. Rustling leaves. The soothing orchestra of windy strings and hooting owls carried me along. Into the darkness. Into the mouth of the forest. A fork in the path and my nerve frantically tried to escape in both directions. A leering sound from the shadows on my right sent me to the left toward an open door. The door wouldn't close behind me so I hid in the corner of pale room silently for two full minutes to listen for the same leering sound. It was nothing. Or it was waiting.

My neck was on fire and my hands leaden. An owl hooted. It was nothing. I kept moving. When I was upstairs I discovered a flashlight and beamed it through a window out into the night. Had I seen something move over by that large house? No it was just my eyes adjusting to the brilliant light. I didn't realize how dark it actually was outside.

Or how alive.

Category        Rating (out of 10)                Controls - A little stiff and unexplained.        7                Visuals - Muted but realistic tones. Very dark but appropriately so. Very simple geometry and effects but not distracting from overall experience IMO.        7                Audio - Completely immersing. Score is rich and dynamic, seamless transitions and powerful. Just the right amount of emotional influence. Auxiliary sounds are very directional and unnerving.        10                Atmosphere - I was totally spooked out between the dark shadowy visuals and edgy audio. I often froze in fear like a deer in headlights, stiff and uneasy. Immersion only snagged slightly when I had trouble entering a few doors or climbing stairs because of a clipping problem.         9                Play length - Less than an hour if you take your time. Looks like some people have finished the game in less than five minutes.        6                Overall - The game is free and many players will appreciate the immersion if they set the tone in their environment. (Play at night, with the lights off, with headphones on).        8/10

Passing Pineview Forest is an interesting and quite suspenseful game.  The first things that caught my attention were the environment and ambience of the forest.  The thought alone of walking through an unfamiliar forest at night gives me a very uneasy feeling.  My favorite thing about the game would have to be the music and environmental audio. I did notice something that bothered me, but being mini-prequel game I don't much care at this point.  The playable area is not very expansive.  When I imagine a forest, I visualize walking most anywhere and creating my own path.

Overall, I enjoyed this game and look forward to future work in this series.

reviewText:
Passing Pineview Forest... Why does this even exist?

Just a little note: I haven't played Pineview Drive yet. Since this is the prequel, I figured I'd start with it.

Okay, let's get the good out of the way - the audio and music is pretty damn good. The rustling of leaves, the owl's hooting, it's all great. The music, even though it's commonly used as a form of jump scare, is quite foreboding and was probably the biggest cause of chills in the game.
Visually? As far as I could tell, it looked fine. PPF is an incredibly dark game, so seeing the little details is really a challenge.

So I've talked about all the good things in PPF, so what about the bad? The gameplay consists of the player walking down a linear path through Pineview Forest, occasionally walking pass statues and houses, some of which are even explorable. The path forks a few times throughout the game, but choosing to go either left or right really doesn't matter, as the two paths always end up meeting further ahead. I feel this prequel would have been vastly better had there been more paths, or if the current path had been anything other than a straight line.

reviewText:
I got so scared I turned down the volume and ran through with my flashlight on trying to die. Only made it to like a chapel thing. Won't play it again.

But it's pretty atmospheric, and the use of empty space rather than a claustrophobic environment makes anything you came across even more unsettling. It's not run'n'hide, or sneak'n'hide. It's walk in the open and hope that noise was nothing, no protection. You feel no more safe in a cabin you come across than out on the path. You feel no more safe sitting in a corner than running. The game preys on your tension and indecisiveness, creating a mood of urgency with no escape. It plays a bit like Slender but less fun and more scary.

The idea is barely different enough from other games to offer some freshness. The game is easy to appreciate if you understand how most other horror games work. It's nice, but unrefined. Worth a try.

reviewText:
Passing Pineview Forest will play with your mind. You can walk, run, use a flashlight, or jump, and that's it. The atmosphere of this game is what makes it scary, along with the game over jumpscare. The graphics are nice, but not extraordinary. Your only objective is to make it to the end of the forest, which seems simple (and in all actuality it is), but ends up leaving you feeling like you need to curl up in a corner and turn all the lights on in your house. When successfully played, the game is only about 20 minutes long, but it will likely take more than a couple of tries to finish it. Possible spoilers below.







This game took me three tries to complete. The first two times, I used a combination of running and walking with my flashlight constantly on and would die right after the statue by the church. The third time, I ran up until the point and walked the rest of the way for the most part, with my flashlight off the entire time. Honestly you need to fail once or twice to get the full experience of this game. Failing gives you a decent jumpscare, which is admittedly pretty poor horror, but it does its job in this title. To be successful, don't use your flashlight, and stop to look around when you hear noises and / or footsteps. You won't see anything, but you also won't get attacked.

reviewText:
This, this is horror.
You're dropped into a forest with the only goal being to make it to end and do it quietly otherwise the forest will claim you, whatever that means.

So, you're in a dark forest with nothing other than a flashlight, with nothing else to do you start going forward. An owl hoots, nothing that bad.
Then you hear movement in the bushes. You stop and turn but nothings there. You keep moving, resisting the urge to run as the rustling bushes become your unwanted companion.

Then you hear footsteps.

Once again you stop but see nothing. After calming down a bit you continue onward, the rustling occasionally being replaced with the footsteps of, whatever it is thats in the forest with you.

I'm not even sure i finished the demo, don't want to spoil anything but I got a game over that caused me to NOPE the ♥♥♥♥ out.
As a fan of horror, I would definitely recommend this and the game it ties to. This is horror done right for once, I saw one jump scare and that was the game over

The one thing it does that most horror doesn't do nowadays is build atmosphere and its nearly on par with older silent hill games. it uses sound and music to unnerve you and get you feeling anxious about what might be in the forest, but you never see it, leading you to imagine what it is. This is how you do horror since the imagination can conjure up creatures and monsters that the devs could never think up, adding to the atmoshpere as your imagination takes over and puts the image of the worst monster you can think of in your mind.

Not a bad game, but it certainly tests your limits. It's rather clever in it's execution, imho. Hear noises? Footsteps coming up behind you? Stop! Whatever you do, don't run...or walk. It's our natural instinct to run from things that scare us. But this evilly challenges that instinct and makes you yield to your fear. Very clever, indeed.

My only real gripe with the game is that the music tends to get too loud and you can't hear your surroundings. Let's be honest, if you were actually walking in a forest there wouldn't be any scary music playing in the background. I wish I could at least turn it down or completely off. To me the music really spoils the mood and takes something away from the game. Yes, it's spooky but that's not my problem with it.
